anchor.surface_text: Section .12. Pending proceedings in other courts not to be affected - Nothing in this Act shall apply to any proceedings pending on the date of the commencement of the West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment  Special Courts  Amending Ordinance, 1952, in any court other than a Special Court.

concepts.interpretation: Bars application of Act to proceedings pending in ordinary courts (not Special Courts) on 9-4-1952; prevents fresh allotment of such pending cases to Special Courts as evasion; but overridden by binding prior High Court decisions vesting jurisdiction in Special Court.

issues.text: What is the effect of the order of the High Court dated 4.4-52? By quashing the proceedings before the special judge, did it or did it not automatically re-invest the Chief Presidency Magistrate with jurisdiction over the case and the offence of which he had taken cognizance?

If [the 4-4-52 order re-invests jurisdiction in Chief Presidency Magistrate], then on the terms of s. 12, the special judge would have no jurisdiction, unless by reason of later decisions binding on the parties, effect cannot be given to this position.

anchor.surface_text: If it has this result, then on the terms of s. 12, the special judge would have numberJurisdiction, unless by reason of later decisions binding, on the parties, effect cannot be given to this position.

issues.text: Does an incorrect decision equate to a decision rendered without jurisdiction such that it is not binding?

anchor.surface_text: A wrong decision by a court having jurisdiction is as much binding between the parties as a right one and may be superseded only by appeals to higher tribunals or other procedure like review which the law provides.

issues.text: Assume that a proceeding was pending in the court of the Chief Presidency Magistrate on 9-4-52. That however does not preclude the State Government from initiating fresh proceedings in respect of the same offences against the accused and allotting that case for trial to the Special judge under s. 4(2)?

Pending proceedings in other courts number to be affected - Nothing in this Act shall apply to any proceedings pending on the date of the commencement of the West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment  Special Courts  Amending Ordinance, 1952, in any court other than a Special Court.

arguments.court_reasoning: Yes on terms of s.12 but later binding decisions prevent giving effect; Special Court jurisdiction upheld between parties

arguments.claim: Proceedings initiated by allotment and charge-sheet on 18-6-1953 not hit by s.12 as fresh after 9-4-1952

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges held that s. 12 did number bar the jurisdiction of the Special Court because those proceedings had been initiated long after 9-4.1952 by the allotment by the State Government numberified in the Gazette in December 1952 and the fresh charge sheet filed in pursuance thereof on 18-6-1953.

arguments.court_reasoning: Binding as between parties despite later superseding events

arguments.claim: By reason of High Court order dated 4-4-1952 and s.12, proceedings pending before Chief Presidency Magistrate on 9-4-1952; Special Judge no jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: the learned judges of the High Court accepted the petition and quashed the orders of the Special judge-and held that by reason of the order of the High Court dated 4-4-1952 quashing the allotment as well as the charge-sheet filed before the special judge, the proceedings were pending before the Chief Presidency Magistrate on 9.4.52.

arguments.court_reasoning: Erroneous; prior binding decisions vested jurisdiction in Special Court between parties

holdings.text: A wrong decision by a court having jurisdiction is as much binding between the parties as a right one and may be superseded only by appeals to higher tribunals or other procedure like review which the law provides.

anchor.surface_text: A wrong decision by a court having jurisdiction is as much binding between the parties as a right one and may be superseded only by appeals to higher tribunals or other procedure like review which the law provides.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes erroneous decision on merits by competent court from lack of jurisdiction; res judicata binds parties regardless of correctness.

holdings.text: By quashing the proceedings before the special judge, the High Court order dated 4-4-1952 automatically re-invested the Chief Presidency Magistrate with jurisdiction over the case and the offence of which he had taken cognizance, leaving proceedings pending there on 9-4-1952.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Quashing invalid allotment restores pre-allotment position where Magistrate had taken cognizance and was seized of proceedings; ministerial transfer order ineffective.

holdings.text: Though s.12 bars Special Judge jurisdiction due to proceedings pending in Magistrate's court on 9-4-1952, later binding High Court decisions (including 19-12-1956) preclude giving effect to this, vesting jurisdiction in Special Court between parties.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Binding effect of subsequent High Court orders (12-1-1956 upheld, 22-2-1956 Special Judge order accepted by State, 19-12-1956) supersedes strict s.12 application; res judicata on jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The present proceedings initiated by allotment and charge-sheet (post-1957) are not hit by s.12 as jurisdiction vested in Special Court by binding prior decisions between parties.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of binding High Court adjudications on jurisdiction overrides strict textual bar of s.12 for these parties.

holdings.text: Pending proceedings in Chief Presidency Magistrate on 9-4-1952 preclude State Government from initiating fresh proceedings in respect of same offences and allotting to Special Judge under s.4(2); would evade s.12.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12 prohibits allotment of pending cases; fresh proceedings on same facts/offences/accused lack substantial identity evasion; manifest object protects ordinary court proceedings.

holdings.text: The Special Court must be deemed to have jurisdiction over the case; High Court order dated 9-5-1958 set aside, appeal allowed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above holdings to facts: binding prior jurisdictional determinations vest trial authority in Special Court.
